column16: Under normal circumstances, we would have not supported the remuneration report to reflect our concerns regarding threshold vesting levels under the LTIP. The achievement of threshold performance conditions (only) results in vesting of 20% (in respect of the absolute TSR target) and 25% of the award potential (in respect of median relative TSR), and this level of vesting represents 90% of salary which we consider to be overly generous for this level of performance. Also, the CEO's bonus opportunity is very high (the same as the LTIP opportunity) at 400% of salary. However, we have exceptionally supported as we are mindful that salaries continue to be positioned at lower quartile (using a balanced comparison) and as variable awards are based off of salaries, the outcomes are not as problematic as they first appear. Also, pay and performance for the year under review were reasonably aligned.

column4: We were concerned that there was no disclosure of performance targets which determine vesting of the Long Term Incentive Plan. We were concerned regarding the pay for performance alignment. Concerns have been identified with the departing CEO's exit arrangements, in particular the Company's decision to pro-rate his outstanding LTIP awards until after his retirement date and following a further 12 month period during which time he will provide advisory services to the Company. Furthermore, the Company has chosen to accelerate vesting of these awards to 30 June 2024 and estimate the performance for the ensuing year in determining the amount that should vest. Lastly, he is not subject to the post-vesting holding period for the LTIP awards. The incoming CEO received a one-off exceptional award to incentivise a strategic initiative.
column8: AllianzGI believes that all incentive awards should be time pro-rated and tested for performance, including in the event of an early termination due to the change of control. Termination payments following a change of control should be similar to those available under normal circumstances. AllianzGI expects clear disclosure of KPIs under all management incentive plans to enable investors to better assess the link between management incentives and corporate strategy and performance.

column96: The board is responsible for attracting the right CEO and setting appropriate remuneration. A substantial proportion of annual remuneration should be provided as shares that are locked in for five to ten years, regardless of resignation or retirement. The board should provide transparency on total remuneration to avoid unacceptable outcomes. The board should ensure that all benefits have a clear business rationale. Pensionable income should constitute a minor part of total remuneration.CEO remuneration

column16: Under normal circumstances, we would not have supported this item on account of our concerns over (i) lack of an executive shareholding requirement; (ii) LTIP being cash settled as awarded in phantom shares and includes an element of restricted shares; and a (iii) lack of post-vesting holding periods and post-cessation shareholding requirements. However, we note that the CEO is based in Chile and is not a member of the Main Board. While, the policy falls short of UK best market practice requirements, we take cognisance of the fact that the remuneration is structured in a way that is suitable for the Chilean market, we are supporting this item on an exceptional basis this year.

column16: Under normal circumstances, we would not be able to support this resolution, as we have concerns on the lack of performance targets in the cash flow and ROCE elements of awards granted under its LTIP. These targets are commercially sensitive and, as such, they will be disclosed retrospectively post vesting, mitigating our concerns. Restricted share awards granted to US executives are not subject to performance and time-vest based solely on continued employment. The board'states this award package ensures competitiveness with US market practice, and that such awards are not granted to UK-based executives. Such awards to US executives are limited to 150% of base salary, and the majority of their equity-award package is subject to performance. The CEO:Employee pay ratio is more than 191:1 and is considered excessive. The pay ratio has been impacted by the increase in the CEO's remuneration for 2023, primarily as a result of share price appreciation on the 2021 Performance Share award between the grant and vesting dates. We note UK employees received a c.6% pay increase in 2023 and will receive increases in 2024 averaging 4.5% for executives and 5.2% for employees. The LTIP meeting threshold performance conditions will result in vesting of 25% of the award potential, and this level of vesting represents approx. 92.5% of salary. We consider this to be excessive. Given the mitigating factors cited above, we are exceptionally voting in favour on this occasion.

column16: We are relatively comfortable with pay outcomes for FY23 (NB: the total compensation / single figure for the interim CEO, Murray Auchincloss for 2023 was approx 8m sterling pounds compared to approx 10.3m sterling pounds for the former CEO, Bernard Looney), given the main concerns we raised ahead of the 2024 AGM were in respect of the former CEO's LTIP outcomes. Given the circumstances of the former CEO's departure, Bernard Looney's pay will be under the spotlight but in our view It's not likely to receive much shareholder opposition, because (as announced by the Company on 13 Dec 2023) he was not be paid a bonus for 2023 and will not be entitled to unvested performance share awards or deferred bonuses. We welcome that clawback has been applied. Another notable point is that the Remuneration Committee reduced the management's bonuses from 82% to 79.5% of max to reflect a fatality during the year.

column4: We have concerns regarding the significant vesting outcome of the 2021 Long Term Incentive Plan. While we recognise that there was no significant reduction in share price between the awards granted May and June 2021, we have concerns that the company reverted to a 300% of salary incentive award and there was no subsequent adjustment on vesting for windfall gains despite the depressed share price at grant. We additionally have concerns regarding the reputational impact of such a significant award.

column74: A vote against is warranted as the annual bonus paid out by reference to non-financial performance despite the Company incurring a statutory loss for the year and despite significant depreciation in shareholder value. We acknowledge and understand the importance of some of these non-financial metrics such as Safer Betting and Gaming. However, given the overall shareholder experience a vote against is deemed appropriate.

column8: AllianzGI encourages companies to include ESG KPIs in their remuneration policy.
column16: Under normal circumstances we would have voted against the Remuneration Report as the CEO: Employee pay ratio is 138:1 having increased since the previous year (97:1) and under the LTIP (CIP and PSP), meeting threshold performance conditions will result in vesting of 25% of the award potential, which represents a total of 100% of salary. Also, there continue to be no ESG metrics incorporated into remuneration plans. However, this is not a vote against as no concerns have been identified with regards to executive pay nor its ratio with median employee pay and we acknowledge the strong performance of the Company for the year under review which resulted in an increase in the CEO's single figure, primarily driven by the value of the LTI. Further, we note certain principal ESG-related business risks and the Company has separately set quantitative targets to support sustainable business strategy (improving financial health, diversity and environment). The company has notably set environmental goals that focus on carbon footprint reduction, and have had'SBT'-approved targets as well. We would welcome an incorporation of these risks and measurements into variable pay frameworks to ensure that there is a linkage between sustainability and executive pay.

column16: Under normal circumstances, we would have voted against the remuneration report to reflect that the new CEO has been appointed on a higher salary and has more variable pay opportunity than his predecessor. Typically we would expect new executives to prove themselves in the role first before getting paid more. However, we have exceptionally supported as we are mindful that the total pay opportunity for the previous CEO was quite conservative, a point which the company alludes to. The company also explains that, in acknowledgment of the fact that his pay would be higher than Nigel Wilson's, the Committee'sought to deliver the majority of the increase through variable pay rather than fixed pay, to ensure that a material portion of pay was linked to performance. This allowed the Committee to moderate the level of fixed pay required to secure Mr Simoes' appointment. Finally our view is that the new CEO has a good pedigree and has been impressive to date. Nevertheless the company is aware that we will be closely watching any salary increase and bonus outcomes closely next year.

column4: We were concerned regarding the pay for performance alignment. The Company's remuneration policy received significant dissent at the 2023 AGM (46% against) in light of concerns around the substantial increase in both the annual bonus and LTIP maximum opportunities. Despite the level of dissent recorded, no material actions have been taken to the remuneration arrangements to address the concerns.Concerns remain on the subjective nature of the Co-Investment Award's performance underpins and their sufficiency and appropriateness to justify the substantial payout. It is, however, recognised that the Remuneration Committee has provided commentary in the annual report on its assessment of the performance underpins. This scheme was previously supported by majority of shareholders, albeit not without notable dissents.

column96: The board is responsible for attracting the right CEO and setting appropriate remuneration. A substantial proportion of annual remuneration should be provided as shares that are locked in for five to ten years, regardless of resignation or retirement. The board should provide transparency on total remuneration to avoid unacceptable outcomes. The board should ensure that all benefits have a clear business rationale. Pensionable income should constitute a minor part of total remuneration.

column4: We have had long standing concerns regarding the quantum of potential variable reward to executive directors. Mindful of the change to CEO during 2023, we are broadly comfortable with the level of grants awarded prior to his appointment as CEO and outcomes for the year. We note that a further vote on Remuneration Policy will be due in 2025 and will review any changes and consider our position ahead of that vote. We consider an abstention to be appropriate in view of our comfort with 2023 outcomes, and our ongoing reservations regarding potential reward quantum.
column16: No comment available
column36: High Payout Ratio Despite Reduced Profits: Despite a decline in profits this year, total short-term remuneration remains above 150% of base salary, and total variable compensation exceeds 350% of base salary. This high payout ratio raises serious concerns about whether executive pay aligns with company performance. * Lack of Product Safety Consideration: The current variable pay structure fails to consider product quality and safety. This is especially concerning in light of the recent high-profile lawsuit against the company's Enfamil infant formula, linked to a tragic infant death. We advocate for a dedicated ESG metric directly linked to product safety mechanisms, such as product recall rates, product liability claims, or safety incidents. These factors should directly impact executive compensation. * Incomplete ESG Metrics with Scope 3 Emissions Gap: The current ESG metrics, which only account for 10% of long-term incentive conditions, focus solely on Scopes 1 and 2 of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. This approach neglects Scope 3, the largest contributor to the company's overall footprint. While we acknowledge the commitment to reduce Scope 3 emissions and its inclusion in the "Sustainable Innovation Calculator" metric, we believe a dedicated incentive focused solely on Scope 3 reduction is necessary. The current link between Scope 3 progress and executive compensation remains unclear, potentially allowing for diluted reduction efforts. Recommendations for improvement: We urged the consumer goods company to revise the compensation structure to better reflect company performance and prioritise product safety. This could involve tying a higher proportion of variable pay to achieving specific performance goals, including those related to product safety. Implement a dedicated ESG metric explicitly linked to Scope 3 GHG emission reduction progress, with a clear and transparent link to payout levels.
column64: We consider the quantum of the total pay excessive.
column126: We have concerns with maximum awards under the LTIP continuing to be indexed to a number of shares as opposed to a multiple of base salary. We believe that setting an individual cap as a percentage of base salary (rather than as a fixed number of shares/options) would help to assure shareholders that executive pay will always be constrained by certain limits.
column176: We have had long standing concerns regarding the quantum of potential variable reward to executive directors. Mindful of the change to CEO during 2023, we are broadly comfortable with the level of grants awarded prior to his appointment as CEO and outcomes for the year. We note that a further vote on Remuneration Policy will be due in 2025 and will review any changes and consider our position ahead of that vote. We consider an abstention to be appropriate in view of our comfort with 2023 outcomes, and our ongoing reservations regarding potential reward quantum.

column16: Under normal circumstances, we would not be able to support this resolution due to a few concerns: - The pay ratio has increased considerably between 2022 and 2023 (from 120:1 to 198:1), which is largely attributable to the value of long-term incentive awards which vested in the past fiscal year. - Under the LTIP, meeting threshold performance conditions will result in vesting of 25% of the award potential (20% from 2024 ), and this level of vesting represents approximately 112.5% of salary (90% of salary from 2024). - Vesting under the ROIC element of the FY2023 awards granted under the long-term incentive plan is based on performance against targets as measured in the final year of the vesting period only, we acknowledge performance will be measured over the full three-year period for FY2024 awards. We are exceptionally supporting on this occasion due to financial performance over the period and our concerns on the LTIP and ROIC vesting will be mitigated in 2024 with the adoption of the remuneration policy. We are also cogniSant'the pay ratio is represented by UK employees only which is less than 20% of its global workforce, we would like to see the wider workforce represented in this ratio.

column2: Approve Remuneration Report for UK Law Purposes
column16: Under normal circumstances we would vote against the remuneration report, as the CEO: Employee pay ratio has increased from 52.00:1 to 97:1, representing a significant increase from the previous year. Concerns also remain with the structure of the LTIP in that 22.5% of the award vests for the achievement of threshold performance targets (i.e median TSR performance) which we think is too generous given awards this level of vesting represents approximately 90.00% of salary. Further, if approved under resolution 2, award levels will increase from 400% to 500% of salary for both Executive Directors'compounding our concerns over the amount of salary in shares vesting for threshold performance. However, we have exceptionally supported on this occasion as the increased CEO pay ratio is primarily due to the vesting of the CEO's first full LTIP award from 2019 which vested at 94.1% at the end of the 2023 performance year. Regarding our concerns over the LTIP, the Committee has stated that the proposed cap of at 500% of salary would position award levels closer to FTSE 10 peers where the median LTIP maximum award is in excess of 500% of salary, yet still materially below US pay levels. In the interest of talent retention and the increase is solely linked to decarbonisation (a key issue for us) we are comfortable in supporting this resolution.
column36: Total variable remuneration is more than 350 percent of base salary.
column64: We consider the quantum of the total pay excessive.
column126: While we continue to commend the company's current efforts and improvements when it comes to implementing the actions from the Everyday Respect Report we would question whether the targets set for the annual bonus regarding the completion rates of the "Building Everyday Respect" employee training program were sufficiently stretching for the year under review, especially given the seriousness of issues in this area that need to be addressed. We will look forward to further engagement with the company and next year's disclosures, when a final independent progress report will be undertaken to ensure that the company continues its progress.
column158: We have concerns regarding the alignment of pay with performance.

column16: Under normal circumstances we would vote against the remuneration report, as the CEO: Employee pay ratio has increased from 52.00:1 to 97:1, representing a significant increase from the previous year. Concerns also remain with the structure of the LTIP in that 22.5% of the award vests for the achievement of threshold performance targets (i.e median TSR performance) which we think is too generous given awards this level of vesting represents approximately 90.00% of salary. Further, if approved under resolution 2, award levels will increase from 400% to 500% of salary for both Executive Directors'compounding our concerns over the amount of salary in shares vesting for threshold performance. However, we have exceptionally supported on this occasion as the increased CEO pay ratio is primarily due to the vesting of the CEO's first full LTIP award from 2019 which vested at 94.1% at the end of the 2023 performance year. Regarding our concerns over the LTIP, the Committee has stated that the proposed cap of at 500% of salary would position award levels closer to FTSE 10 peers where the median LTIP maximum award is in excess of 500% of salary, yet still materially below US pay levels. In the interest of talent retention and the increase is solely linked to decarbonisation (a key issue for us) we are comfortable in supporting this resolution.
column36: The proposed increased in LTI opportunity for the CEO from 400% to 500% of base salary coupled with a reduced performance period of 3 years (from 5 years) is a regressive step and inconsistent with Australian market practice. - There are climate goals in the STI (10%) and LTI (20%), which potentially may have the effect of rewarding executives twice for the same outcome. As the STI goals are disclosed on a retrospective basis, this will reviewed ahead of the 2025 AGM. - LTI grant to EDs were not put to a shareholder vote and there is no resolution put at this AGM for the FY24 LTI grant. This represents a material inconsistency with good corporate governance practice in Australia, although it is fully consistent with UK market practice and standards where remuneration policy approval is the main shareholder approval mechanism.

We will look forward to further engagement with the company and next year's disclosures when a final independent progress report will be undertaken to ensure that the company continues its progress.

column4: We have been unsupportive of the company's Remuneration Policy, and consequently its Remuneration Report, in recent years. Our concerns relate to the absence of a specific cap on the annual bonus scheme. While in 2020 the company introduced an overall cap on total remuneration at time of grant for the CEO (9m sterling pounds) and CFO (4.5m sterling pounds), the bonus does not have an underlying limit which we expect to see. There is a limit on the Long-Term Incentive, of 4x salary, however awards in practice have been far lower - at 1.2x and 1x. Therefore the bonus potential, taking account of the total remuneration cap, is significant when considering the executive salary and LTI grant level. We do note that executives have not received salary increases, the bonus outcome was reduced by 250k sterling pounds to reflect shareholder experience and there was no LTI vesting in FY23 due to the waiving of awards during the pandemic in 2020. However in view of our ongoing reservations regarding the absence of an individual cap on the annual bonus, we have voted against.

column36: Total remuneration is more than two times the median of peers. Pleae note that:- Pay within the sector as a whole is controversial , given the focus on river pollution. In Severn Trent's case, a GBP 2 million fine was imposed this year, due to a pollution incident in 2019-2020, with reputational consequences.However, the issues besetting the Company are not unique to it. In fact, Severn Trent is the only company in the sector to consistently attain 4 star EA status. There have been no serious pollution incidents during the year, and the proportion of pay geared towards river health has increased, with the occurrence of a serious pollution incident serving as an underpin to automatically reduce outcomes, going forward. See Material Company Updates for further context.

column16: Under normal circumstances, we would not support the remuneration report proposal based on our concerns regarding the 12% increase in the CFO's salary (that follows a 5% increase in 2023). However, and while we would have preferred a staggered approach to this increase, we have exceptionally supported the remuneration report proposal in recognition of the broad range of responsibilities of the CFO, including the expansion of the company's M&A activity in the last year. There are also some concerns regarding the structure of the LTIP as the achievement of threshold performance conditions result in vesting of 25% of the award potential, and given the CEO's recent share grants are valued at 344% of salary and 288% for the CFO this level of vesting represents more than 75% of salary, which in our view is generous particularly in the context of the recent performance of the business.

column1: Weir Group Plc (The Weir Group Plc)
column16: Under normal circumstances we would vote against this resolution, however we are exceptionally voting in favour as: There was a downward adjustment from 18.08% to 17.64% to the 2023 ESG bonus outcome to account for injuries inadvertently excluded from prior year TIR rates. The Committee also made an aggregate reduction to the 2020 RSA of 12.5% to take into account the market volatility at the time of grant and concern around the potential for perceived 'windfall gains'. We are mindful the CEO's salary will be increased by 4% to 829,000 sterling pounds from 1 April 2024, in line with the average increase for the wider UK workforce. Further, the CFO'stepped down from the Board on 30 November 2023 and his unvested RSAs lapsed. His successor was appointed on 1 March on a salary broadly at the same level. He will receive estimated buyout awards equal to 2,016,000 sterling pounds which are designed on a like-for-like basis to the awards forfeited with the previous employer. We believe the board'should undertake a review of its succession planning to ensure that such awards are not necessary in the future.
column36: Mr Puffer received Weir share awards, some are not subject to any performance conditions, to recompense him for the share awards that he forfeited on leaving his previous employer.
